comments.commentBody: Much more love for this one than yesterday's.  Today's puzzle required the deciphering of clever clues that lead to "Aha" moments.  Yesterday's was full of obscurities that led to "What the...?" moments.

Yes, IT"S A LULU, but it might be my fastest Saturday solve ever. I was helped to the answer of 23D because coincidentally we watched "This Is It" this afternoon, which includes the song "Billy Jean." And not only have I read many novels by Vargas Llosa, but I had the opportunity to meet him when his play "Kathy y el Hipopotamo" was presented in Miami.

SERAPES, ESTAMPA and MARTES seems to be an excess of Spanish in this puzzle, but I'm not complaining.

The details of the construction are wasted on me; I solve them and don't know a fig about grids or blocks or white spaces, or inner staircases etc., etc, etc. Puzzles for me are about words and clever constructors testing our abilities, not the inside baseball of construction achievements. I don't mean to belittle the intricacies of constructing, just want to stress that I'm a solver freak, not a construction maven.

Joe Krozel has been a particularly tough solve in the past and this puzzle was much more accessible than his usual offerings. There seemed to be a lot of clues which were rather straightforward such as "Lacking luster" for MATTE; "Big name in Top 40 countdowns" which is a gimme for KASEM;"Proverbial certainty" for TAXES (Death took a pass, fortunately); "Throttle:Var." for GAROTTE and many more, which I won't try to list, but all together they provided the crosses which allowed the sorting out of the "fearful fifteens"

Among the long answers, CULTUREVULTURES was great fun while TENYEARSENTENCE as an answer to the clue "It's better than life" was awkward, at best. The rest of the lengthy entries were quite gettable, with varying degrees of difficulty; being more serviceable than "drop dead" clever.

Overall a good workout from Joe Krozel even though I guess I'm only appreciating half of his achievement.

Somehow we got on Worcester today. (Actually I started it.) Well, there's a Wooster in Ohio (also discussed today).

So I went to Wikipedia for Wooster, Ohio. First, it WAS named for a Revolutionary War hero, General David Wooster - as someone had suggested. And, second, Wikipedia says that the "oo" is as in "wood" - which surprised me! That means the city of Worcester (Mass) and the city of Wooster (Ohio) are pronounced identically (well, mostly, at least)!

I had always assumed that the "oo" in Wooster was as in "hoot." Luckily, one of my mottos is: Why guess when you can look it up!

-- jpgaskell

Joe's comments were a bit too much inside baseball for me. Fortunately one can enjoy a painting without knowing about how the paint was mixed and the brush strokes were applied. This one today was a masterpiece.

(But I probably wouldn't write that if I hadn't finished it.)

since my original idea proved not so original, I guess I'll have to be daring:

on the gluteals: "devil fetch the hindmost."

Hot  Cold (on chest) --  as a reminder of which faucet is which as seen on a not very bright sailor in an old Jerry Lewis movie.

Hers (somewhere between the suprasternal notch and a low neckline):

"I'd rather jiggle than jog."

His (convex abdominal):

"Fuel tank for a love machine."

(More ingenious than ingenuous, perhaps? Those were the best I could spot at the community pool on a Friday afternoon.)
"I ink therefore I tan."

Big and bold enough to be seen through dense chest hair:

THE PEN IS MIGHTIER THAN THE SWARD.
Freshness Guaranteed until June 1985.
As seen on Facebook
Demonstration only. Do not attempt.
206, you are misinformed.  You cannot collect a pension as a teacher while working in any district in NY State.

Retirees are downright rich compared to the young who have no healthcare, nightmarish student debt, and a bad job market. Retirees and Boomer about to be retirees essentially already get everything government currently provides that isn't military: Medicare, Social Security, Mortgage write off. I know people who worked for housing agencies who get close to their entire salary (for life!) AFTER retiring, in ADDITION to Social Security and Medicare. These people encompass the vast majority of Tea Partiers and conservatives who want to repeal healthcare because it partially benefits younger people.

It is about time that these retirees and Boomers start realizing that they are really not that special. They need to start suffering along with the rest of us. They need to scale back their retiree lifestyles of golf course gated communities and dining out nightly, while they vote to cut every single thing that government can do that doesn't directly benefit them.

The self centeredness of these people is mind boggling. And I haven't even mentioned the huge debt they have left Gen X and Y. But oh yeah, they forget about deficits when it comes to the Bush tax cuts because black people and gays are scary.

The current public pension system is immoral and unfair. People are being taxed to pay for pensions that are very excessive. One only has to compute the net present value of a typical public pension upon retirement to see that.

Legislators are bullied (or bought and paid for) by public unions. These unions operate in an environment of no competition and the only constraint on their compensation is the will of our legislators. These legislators, by the way, often enjoy the same pensions.

This is such a total fiasco! Good grief, who has been managing the money??? Previously, I felt badly for the pensioners who were promised a certain retirement and should get what they were promised. But then I realized something important. My friend Jane, who worked very hard in the private sector and saved diligently for years and years, lost $700,000 in the crash, and will now have to work for many years longer than she had planned. There are millions of others in the private sector just like her, who can't retire when they had planned to because of the crash. So, my feelings have changed. Now I say, too bad for the pensioners whose plans were waylaid - they can go back to work too - just like everybody else. Enough already. The whole economy went upside down - so everyone has to make - in many cases - huge sacrifices. Buck up, pensioners. I'm sorry for you, but I'm just as sorry for the rest of us.

I just graduated from college, and I always tried to buy as many used books as possible. I would email professors before the start of the semester to ask which books were required for purchase and buy those on Amazon. (Make sure to order the books you need in the beginning of the semester right away! You can take your time to search for the best prices on ones you don't need for a month or two...) Sometimes, however, I ran into problems when the professor would change the syllabus before the first class. By my senior year I became so frustrated with the ridiculous cost of a semester's worth of books that I resolved to borrow whichever books I could from the library. Even if our campus library did not have the book in the stacks, I was able to borrow from the Consortium of other DC universities or the DC public libraries. I also found some ebooks accessible through the library website. My advice is to get in touch with your professors early, reserve books from the library, or share with friends if necessary/possible.  When I studied abroad in Egypt, I first was amused to discover that photocopying and spiral-binding books was the norm. But, given the pricey alternative (think new book prices plus import taxes), no one even batted an eyelash at the flagrant copyright violations.

The assumption that all who worked in the public sector would have had higher salaries had they worked in the private sector is questionable. Many public sector jobs have no direct private sector counterparts. To use just one position as an example, I would say that many experienced teachers, of whom there are millions, make as much income on an annualized basis as a low-to-mid-level manager. If these teachers were to leave the profession and enter the private sector, most would not be able to replace their teachers' salaries and benefits, even in good economic times. That is not to say that they are overpaid, but simply to say that the jobs for which they would be qualified, considering the ratio of managers to employees, in the private sector would probably not pay as well.

Public employees whose employment is not covered by Social Security often pay a percentage of their income toward their pension plan; however, unlike Social Security participants having like income, they are not expected to subsidize the retirements of persons earning much less than themselves.

These public pension funding shortfalls have come to light as a result of accounting changes, but they have existed for some time nevertheless. They were simply masked by accounting standards that allowed the use of greatly exaggerated future investment earnings assumptions, the effect of which has been magnified by today's extremely low interest and discount rates, coupled with relaxed funding requirements. Government and church pension plans have for too long been exempt from the strict regulations to which private pension plans are subject. Church plan rules have been so lax that many nonprofit employers having even a nominal connection to a religious group have declared their plans church plans, with disastrous results for the plan participants.

Public sector employees will have to make some compromises, just as private sector employees have. Some of the excess in public pensions could be trimmed if automatic benefit increases were to be eliminated in favor of true cost-of-living allowances, but if retirees resist these and other necessary cost-curtailment measures, their successors, whose work is just as difficult and just as important, will pay the price, through some combination of steep reductions in promised benefits, lower salaries, increased employee contributions to pension plans, or increased service requirements. To assert that one has earned an overly generous pension as a result of dedication to a public service career, even as its requirement of ever-increasing payments will almost certainly result in our inability to provide adequately for the retirement needs of the equally dedicated public servants who follow, is both hypocritical and unfair.

Why on earth do public sector workers get pensions when the rest of us get nothing or 401(k) plans that vaporize with a market downturn? Pensions are dinosaurs, and as a taxpayer, I am sick to death of paying for the pensions of government employees. We taxpayers are TAPPED OUT,

For what it's worth, some of us professors, in the humanities especially, routinely refuse to assign textbooks, precisely because they cost too much as well as because--at least in my opinion--they are boring, poorly-written, and superficial.

I might also say to Dan (#38) that while textbook publishers do need to provide examination copies to professors considering them for a future course, they dump vastly more books on us without our asking for them. It's some kind of tax write-off, or they call it a marketing expense. Do I sell these back to textbook dealers? You bet! Because I don't have enough space in my office for two dozen new textbooks every year, none of which I asked for or plan to use. To throw them all away would be a waste of trees.

Take a look at the Pew report that I linked to from the story. The promises are not (yet) as large and it may be easier to break them or impose cost-sharing on retirees. But even less has been put away to cover these costs (as a percentage of what has been promised) than what has been put away for pensions. Some states have put away nothing, simply paying as they go.
While we taxpayers are feeling outraged, let us not forget the gold-plated health-benefits-for-life many public sector employees get. Doesn't that factor into the budget calculus?

Take a look at the Pew report that I linked to from the story. The promises are not (yet) as large and it may be easier to break them or impose cost-sharing on retirees. But even less has been put away to cover these costs (as a percentage of what has been promised) than what has been put away for pensions. Some states have put away nothing, simply paying as they go.

Wow!  This was hard to get started on.  I couldn't make much headway beyond the lower right quadrant and the last three rows until I gave up and read the blog.  That gave me the start I needed, and I was eventually able to finish the puzzle.  Even for a Saturday, that was a major challenge.  Bravo to Joe Krozel!
